Review: The best adaptation of The Little Mermaid is a neon Polish Eurodance horror musical

I wish the direction was snazzier. Odd to see a musical adaptation with performances this heightened and externalized in a bland backdrop that screams soundstage. Also surprised that Brooks is the one actor who's being singled out; thought she overacted, even for a musical.

Maybe the most I've changed my mind on a rewatch, this is a masterpiece. Lea Seydoux plays the aroace Alma Coin.Mostly a hysterical (and for Lanthimos screenplays, an uncharacteristically legible) takedown of amatonormativity, but like all Lanthimos films it's also about how our environment shapes the constraints of our imagination. At times a frustrating movie to watch because - oddly for a dystopian - there's no lore or explicit reasoning behind the rules of the absurd world that Lanthimos…

Nothing can match the singular tone of what Gene Wilder did (Timmy was serviceable) and none of the new songs or story beats are particularly strong, but Paul King scratches a certain itch. Sufficiently nostalgic without being overly reliant on the original. Kids loved it, I was entertained

So much love emanating from this!A metatextual reading (such as Richard Brody's excellent one for the New Yorker) is much more interesting than the narrative. Modernizing feminine art which was inherently compromised by the male-dominated constraints of the time period is an interesting problem; how much reverence should the adaptation owe to the source material, how much should it recognize and interpret the author's true intent between the lines, and how much liberty does the adapter have to breathe…

The film opens with a Bernstein quote asserting that good art provokes more questions than it answers, but director Cooper seems to have misunderstood ambiguity as a lack of specificity. Though fortunately not a Wikipedia biopic, I wanted SOME deeper context for Leonard's and Felicia's historic lives beyond the overdramatized, surface-deep, and quite straightforward romantic arc we got. A script and structure more in service of Acting Moments than any message or insight. The portrayal of bisexuality was especially reductive,…

So glad I saw this in theaters, the most I've laughed all year. Farcical iconoclasm is Lanthimos's whole thing (maybe the most anarchist mainstream director working today tbh), but he treats his absurd worlds and characters with sincerity, which is why Bella works so well. This is his most accessible - unlike something like Killing of a Sacred Deer, where the vibes are the substance, Poor Things's script is clear with its themes - but it's still quite dense. Props…

The satire promised by the trailer is drowned out by generic Mad Libs family drama that makes up at least three-quarters of the movie, or at least feels like it. There is a point being made by showing this side of Jeffrey Wright's character, but the tension between the private "real" and the public "performed" never really attempts to resolve itself, and I found myself hoping the movie would cut back to being a B-tier social satire every time it…

Movie: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Review: Sticks a little too close to established lore, I was drawn in by some of the hints of worldbuilding (especially around the origin and evolution of the Games) but it's all in service of a mediocre and disjointed plot. Viola Davis MVP

Still works as middle class wish fulfillment, but also (unintentionally?) a great illustration of how entwined 90s malaise was with feelings of emasculation. It's less overt than other 99 movies like Fight Club obviously but the gay jokes, the cucking, the line about "getting beat up", and most of all an almost propagandistic ending celebrating manual labor all make this an interesting dissection of how class and gender anxiety intersect

Movie: How to Blow Up a Pipeline

Review: Love the bit where they do the shining axe scene but Jerry's too much of a beta to even terrorize his wife himself so he has to hire Steve Buscemi to do it
